ratings.comment: His lectures feel longer than they need to be, and yet attending them is still critical. Despite considerable use of R in this course, we're only taught the bare minimum required for assignments. Exam grading criteria is considerably tougher and more mysterious than homework grading. Show up to everything and do your best with what you're given.

Prof. Culberston was actually one of my favorite professors this semester. Culbertson. Prof. Culbertson had an excellent course layout, exams were identical to the homework and things we did in class. He is very responsive on Piazza, and attendance is not mandatory.

Definitely attend lectures, or you probably won't pass. The material is tough, but he does a good job explaining the material in class. Homework assignments pretty much follow the examples from lecture, and doing well on those will help keep your grades up. The class is certainly work, but it's not impossible.

By far the most confusing stats class I have taken. The material itself is not hard but the professor made the class impossible. He literally had the most confusing ways of explaining incredibly simple topics. His teaching style was very convoluted and all lectures were read off a script.

I found his slides really helpful and easy to grasp. I thought the homework grading was a little strange and inconsistent, but if you want to discuss your homework with him, he is ready and willing to help.

Initially I thought he was okay but his grading makes absolutely no sense. I went to all office hours to get the homework done (where the TAs basically walk through the hw) and still got Cs on a lot of assignments. He's inconsistent about grading and doesn't explain concepts to the standard that he expects you to understand them.

He definitely didn't start out good, but toward the end he was great! I think it was his first semester teaching. He uses TopHat in lecture in a way that makes learning the material so much easier. The homeworks are EXACTLY like the tests, which are also open note. The lectures are pretty straightforward which is nice for the exams.

In the beginning of the semester, I really did not like the teacher. I thought the class was super hard and I didnt understand a thing he was talking about. Thats until I actually started looking into what he was talking about. The language he uses may be sophisticated, but the material is actually easy. And the test is open to all recourses!

Culbertson's lecture slides are very vague and his explanations in class make concepts seem more complicated then they really are. Key to this class is staying organized. Tests are open note and discussion + lecture quizzes are easy to do well on if you keep up but homework was hard to do alone, find a study group for this class for sure.

Did not have a great experience in Stat 371 with Culbertson. I found his lecture slides very unhelpful, resources to prepare for the exam confusing and not related to how the exam actually was, and just overall not the best teacher. My one positive I have for him is that he was very accessible during office hours. Avoid taking his class if you can.

Professor Culbertson is a friendly guy, helpful in a 1 on 1 setting, but not a good lecturer. He uses a power point that gives you little to work with. However, the way he teaches the classes forces you to engage and actively think about topics. If you get him, utilize office hours and meet with him outside of class for help and you'll be good.

Professor Culbertson is rarely prepared for lecture and most materials are prepared within 24 hours so students have little time to complete them. He is not a good lecturer and often struggles to explain concepts to students. Grading is not timely, and exams are much different than other homework and material in class. Find another professor!

Professor Culbertson read off of his computer for the entirety of his lectures making it very hard for students to follow along. Get ready to hate TopHat. Dr. Culbertson gives TopHat quizzes every lecture. These questions are extremely difficult. He will explain the question concepts after he gives the question. Homework takes 5-10 hours each week.

Professor Culbertson's lectures can often be a little tricky and leave you more confused than when you came. The homework assignments connect to class work loosely and are somewhat difficult to comprehend, since they're never discussed in discussion. However, Professor Culbertson is respectful.

Prof. Culbertson is a genuine person, and I believe he cares about his students. However, his lectures are very difficult to understand. He speaks hypothetically and does not offer many real life examples. His responses in piazza are often vague. Stats is a difficult course to teach but there is room for improvement. Test are open resources.

I think people are pretty harsh on him and he's not a bad professor at all. Some of his wording is super confusing and convoluted, but you can start to understand his language as the course progresses. He includes everything you need in the lecture slides; he's pretty well organized. Overall he's kind of funny but definitely not the worst.

Professor Culbertson is an extremely genuine guy and its clear that he cares about the success of his students. I truly dont understand the bad reviews he gets. Exams are online and open note. You have every resource available to you to succeed. Lectures can be tricky, but its because he wants you to think and not be spoon fed like high school.

Lectures are often confusing and are made to confuse students by going over why each question could possibly be right. Top hat are graded and often not explained, thus, you have to go back into your own time and re-do quizzes to get back points that you missed that were way out of your control to earn. DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS PROFESSOR!

Lectures consist of reading off an script and attempting to confuse students with answers. Participation is at an all time low and no one wants to answer any of his questions because no one knows what he's talking about. Homework is often long and not explained in class. Not recommended.

I got a 5 on the AP Stats test in HS & I think this prof made Stats way harder than it should be. Culby CAN'T teach. He reads off a script during lectures (using unnecessarily big words to make him seem smarter)&grades understanding of new material DURING lecture. Don't try to ask him a question, bc he will not know the answer. DONT TAKE HIS CLASS!

Frustrating and difficult course. Does not explain concepts well nor does he give us the right answers for tophat, which is also graded on accuracy based off concepts we have not learned. Lectures are not recorded so if you miss class, good luck. Slides make 0 sense and is extremely unhelpful. Everyone is confused in this class. Don't take stat371.

I am appalled at such a terrible professor that is even allowed to "teach" his students. This is not teaching. I have put in timeless hours for this class and am still almost failing. Someone needs to report his "teaching" as this is disturbing to see as a part of the statistics community here. Students deserve better,give us an A,and stop teaching

I have never, ever taken a class with a more dysfunctional professor and curriculum. I thought I was taking statistics, and I did not know that there wouldn't even be math or anything logical. Never have I ever had a professor teach me histograms for an hour and be confused on it, HOW DO YOU MAKE HISTOGRAMS CONFUSING? You attend lecture or fail.
He could talk for hours but never really say anything at all. avoid at all costs

The way he lectures makes no sense and is really difficult to follow and understand. All the practice problems you do in class and for homework are COMPLETELY different than what you will see on the exams. The exams are from left field and make no sense. DO NOT TAKE THIS PROF
Grades understanding in lectures but doesnt even teach the content beforehand, presents a slideshow instead of teaching the content, unclear about a lot of the content even after explaining it
